required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Short-term Effects of Postural Taping on Pain and Neck Posture
clinical_study.official_title: Short-term Effects of Postural Taping on Pain and Neck Posture: a Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of a short treatment period with Balance Body Tape on the intensity of perceived neck, shoulder and back pain and neck posture.

detailed_description.textblock:
The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of a short treatment period with Balance Body Tape on the intensity of perceived neck, shoulder and back pain and neck posture.
Method 26 subjects who reported being university students or having a sedentary work and experiencing pain in neck, back or shoulders were randomized into intervention- (n=12) and control group (n=14).
The intervention group received a three-week treatment with BBT, the control group received no treatment. A questionnaire regarding pain, including a Numeric Rating Scale (NRS) measuring pain intensity, and a Photographic posture analysis measurement (PPAM) of habitual sitting posture were accomplished before and after the intervention for both groups. WilcoxonÂ´s signed rank test and Mann-Whitney U test was used to assess intra- and between group differences respectively. The relationship between pain intensity and CV-angle was assessed using Spearman's rank-order correlation.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: 26 subjects experiencing pain in neck, back or shoulders were randomized into either an intervention group (n=12) or control group (n=14).

primary_outcome.description: Pain intensity measured by numeric rating scale (NRS) rating from 0-10, where 0=no pain and 10= worst pain
Neck posture measured by the craniovertebral (CV) angle in sagittal plane.

arm_group.description: Three-week treatment with Balance Body Tape (BBT).

intervention.description: The intervention group received a three-week treatment with Balance Body Tape (BBT) (product by Babota AB), the control group received no treatment. A questionnaire regarding pain, including a Numeric Rating Scale (NRS) measuring pain intensity, and a Photographic posture analysis measurement (PPAM) of habitual sitting posture were accomplished before and after the intervention for both groups.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Aged 18-39
- University student or having a sedentary work
- Experienced of neck, shoulder and/or back pain, during prolonged sitting
- Minimum of 2-point score at the Numeric Rating Scale.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Severe back or neck injuries within the last 3 months
- Ongoing treatment plan for any back or neck problems
- Severe contact allergy or eczema
- Previously tried Body Balance Tape.
